title: Rémi Casty
text:
Rémi Casty (born 5 February 1985) is a French professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer and plays for <a href="Toulouse%20Olympique">Toulouse Olympique</a> in the <a href="RFL%20Championship">RFL Championship</a>. He is also a <a href="France%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">French international</a>.
He played for the <a href="Sydney%20Roosters">Sydney Roosters</a> in 2014 before returning to <a href="Catalans%20Dragons">Catalans</a>.
Background.
Casty was born in <a href="Narbonne">Narbonne</a>, <a href="Languedoc-Roussillon">Languedoc-Roussillon</a>, <a href="France">France</a>.
Playing career.
Catalans Dragons.
From being considered something of a fringe player during the Dragons first two seasons in the Super League, Casty matured and became an integral part of the French team, and regularly seen making hard yards from the interchange bench.
Casty enjoyed an excellent season in 2012 which culminated in him being named in the <a href="Super%20League%20Dream%20Team">Super League Dream Team</a>. 
Sydney Roosters.
Casty left Catalans to join <a href="Sydney%20Roosters">Sydney Roosters</a> in 2014, and made his debut for the club in the <a href="2014%20World%20Club%20Challenge">2014 World Club Challenge</a>. In Round 11 of the <a href="2014%20NRL%20season">2014 NRL season</a>, Casty made his <a href="NRL">NRL</a> debut for the Roosters against the <a href="Canterbury-Bankstown%20Bulldogs">Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs</a>. He went on to make 11 further NRL appearances, scoring two tries before rejoining Catalans at the start of the 2015 season.
Catalans Dragons (rejoin).
He played in the <a href="2018%20Challenge%20Cup%20Final">2018 Challenge Cup Final</a> victory over the <a href="Warrington%20Wolves">Warrington Wolves</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium">Wembley Stadium</a>.
Toulouse Olympique.
On 22 Jan 2021 it was reported that he had signed for <a href="Toulouse%20Olympique">Toulouse Olympique</a> in the <a href="RFL%20Championship">RFL Championship</a> Casty retired at the end of the 2021 season having helped Toulouse secure promotion to Super League. He has joined on as assistant head coach for the 2022 season.
International career.
He was a member of the <a href="2013%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup%20squads%23France">France squad</a> for the <a href="2013%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">2013 Rugby League World Cup</a> and appeared in all four of France's matches at the tournament.
He was named in the <a href="France%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">France squad</a> for the <a href="2008%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">2008 Rugby League World Cup</a>. On 3 November 2011, the annual <a href="RLIF%20Awards">RLIF Awards</a> dinner was held at the <a href="Tower%20of%20London">Tower of London</a> where Casty was named the French player of the year.
In October 2016, Casty captained France in their <a href="2016%20Rugby%20League%20Four%20Nations%23France%20vs%20England">end of year test match</a> against England in Avignon. France lost the match 6-40.
